content.body: TabAtkins: yeah I couldn't resist replying to that one, even though I should have
https://gist.github.com/f7d3e10233d436eb16dc comment on HTML6, I can't distill it down in one IRC line
krijnh: thanks for upgrading your sewing machine ;-) logs fully loading again
Hello all
hi
what's the haps, how goes html5?
huh?
http://www.w3.org/html/wg/wiki/HTML5_Authoring_Conformance_Study - why are there fewer, and different conformance errors on google.de compared to other googles?
s/, and different//
I need to switch to an OpenID provider whose authentication page doesn't break in Minefield.
So Wikipedia, Mozilla, and WHATWG get it right, virtuelv.
no, many sites gets it right
with regards to their declared doctypes and intended goals
well yes :)
the thing I find some comfort in, is that for the sites with many errors, the error count goes down when validated against HTML5
virtuelv: the very same reason will no doubt make many people agitated ;-)
hsivonen: are you planning to add an outliner to validator.nu?
virtuelv, how is that a good thing?
You think they'll be encouraged to fix their bugs if they have 10 instead of 20?
The most common validation error I see on corporate sites is improperly escaped / unescaped text.
boblet: yes, in some far future after a Firefox release has been shipped with the HTML5 parser
hehe
hsivonen: here’s hoping that far future isn’t too far, eg for block-level links etc
boblet: I thought we were going to enable the HTML5 parser on the trunk by the end of this month. However, now it seems that that's not going to happen.
boblet: I don't really know what the time scales are
hsivonen: that sucks ;( did something big come up to stop it from happening?
boblet: we don't have continuous integration test coverage for speculative parsing
hsivonen: well … that_sounds_ big… :? hehe
or at least impressive

This seems to be somehwat overstating the abilities of CSS transforms, or am I wrong? "Actually, because CSS3 implements the same functionality as the canvas element (which makes me believe that the canvas element becomes redundant then)"
presumably you can implement <canvas> with <div> and CSS3
but then you can implement CSS3 with <font> and DOM
and sufficiently small font sizes
So we conclude that you can implement <canvas> with <font> and DOM and sufficiently small font sizes
indeed, same for SVG btw
I wonder why we bothered with all this stuff in the first place
anyway, time to go
new passport + presentation coming up
with <font> going through DirectWrite, you even get GPU acceleration if you implement stuff on top of tiny fonts!
goes back to backlog JonathanNeal / boblet : my point is that the HTML5 spec is closer to specifying real authoring practices
if everyone ceased from creating new documents on the web, HTML5 UAs should eventually become more compatible with that content
*interoperable
virtuelv: is this re: the wiki authoring conformance study?
boblet: yes
of course, people will debate whether a specification that actually takes common legacy implementations into account is jumping the shark or not
my take was that those who e.g. advocate draconian error handling will see this as a watering down, a move in the wrong direction
I don't see how anyone can advocate draconian error handling
Dashiva: I expect doing e.g. dynamic edge filtering of videos would be quite tricky with CSS transforms
(but that's a different matter)
draconian error handling is only possible on the syntactic level when you abstract away the syntax and let tools serialize your documents
or when you start from scratch and decree it
boblet: Like with RSS?
has his name in RFC 4287
rss is still not gone :/
had TBL made draconian error handling a basic tenet of HTML from the outset it’s possible that the web would be using it
boblet:
the short answer is "absolutely not"
boblet: I expect the browser developers would have just ignored him
but I completely certain the web would be a shadow of its current state
my thesis is that had TBL made error handling draconian, the web wouldn't have taken off
since they could make their products better for authors and users by violating the spec
virtuelv: yep, that’s what I think
Philip`: I don’t think there would have been a need, as browsers would only have been made/bought by academia and hobbyists
http://www.walterzorn.com/jsgraphics/jsgraphics_e.htm - <canvas>-style graphics using <div>
so it's not merely possible, it's already implemented
Philip`: I seem to recall digg at some point using that library
continues to think that HTML5 shouldn't defer to RFC2119 for definitions of "must" etc, because RFC2119 doesn't make sense in the context of authoring requirements
hmm, yeah, true
(It's written about vendors implementing behaviours)
Philip`: is it really, though?
I'm reading it now and I don't immediately see anything that makes it bound so closely to implementations
to being about requirements for implementors
"the full implications should be understood and the case carefully weighed before implementing any behavior described with this label"
ohg
That's about implementing behaviours
yeah, and "enhances the product while another vendor may omit the same item"
The "MAY" definition is all about vendors and implementations
right
I see that now
the Security Considerations section also

Some of the definitions are more generic, but if the goal was for RFC2119 to apply to non-implementations requirements too then presumably the whole thing would have been written in a more generic way
yes
though perhaps it doesn't really matter what the original intent was
It matters if people start trying to selectively interpret the intent of the original phrasing
FWIW I agree with Philip` to the extent that RFC 2119 is clearly not intended to deal with authoring requirments when the client is liberal
(or perhaps in general)
Philip`: it is a mistake for them to do that
I don't think this is a big problem except insofaras people try to spac lawyer as if it was
I think the use of must/should/etc for authoring requirements is useful and sensible and good, but specs should be clear that it's a wilful violation of RFC2119
so that people can't validly claim that the spec is silently inconsistent with the other specs it normatively references
would prefer people just stopped that because it is obviously a trivial inconsistency, hasn't been a problem for other specs, and only matters to spec lawyers anyway
wonders if 'it should be feasible to explain to authors exactly how to write valid HTML' is one of the criteria that Sam is missing

(where 'to write an attribute value containing a '&', you can write it escaped or you can write '&' unless it's followed by one of these 106 strings of characters in unescaped form' is not considered a feasible explanation)
(...'unless those strings are themselves followed by an alphanumeric character' or whatever the rules are now)
interesting that an engineer from Microsoft Research is implementing a conformant HTML5 parser
http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html-comments/2010Mar/0014.html
I wonder what language he's coding it in

http://langnetsymposium.com/2009/speakers.aspx - "Prior to joining MSR, Herman worked in the Developer Division, initially on JScript .NET. After completing the JScript .NET project Herman worked in collaboration with MSR on Comega and Spec#. Since joining MSR on a full time basis, Herman has worked on Spec#, the Verifying C compiler, CCI version 2 and lately on JScript again (initially in the context of the Gazelle browser project)."
Sounds like he largely works on stuff around C#, so maybe that
that would make sense, I guess
Gazelle uses C# too
(but reusing parts of Trident, like the parser, in the version in the published paper)
I seem to vaguely remember previously hearing about someone already working on a C# HTML5 parser
but maybe I imagined it
anyway, it would seem to be nice to have one
http://code.google.com/p/twintsam/
ah yeah
I rememeber that name now
Thomas Broyer
me tries to remember what "twinstam" means
The Web Is Not Tag Soup Any More
Soup Tags?
<water><rice/><meat state=minced/></water>
I'd use a generic <minced> wrapper element to allow mincing arbitrary ingredients
heh
I want a <mike> tag
we have that tag named after Mark Pilgrim already
so it would only seem fair
if you write enough documents with a <mike> tag doesn't it have to be in html6?
Not if it doesn't have special behavior
i could wave my hands around, would that get it in?
ponders what the behavior of the <mike> tag should be
<device type=microphone>
Morning/afternoon. As a reminder, is this the primary HTML5 channel on IRC?
looks at the channels on the log site in /topic
It's where most discussion about the spec takes place
http://masinter.blogspot.com/2010/03/browsers-are-rails-web-sites-are-trains.html
...then perhaps you guys can be of assistance. I'm still a bit confused by the purpose of the <canvas> element. Is it supposed to allow for drawing whatever you want on it?
It seems rail/train doesn't really match how HTML works. It seems more like ocean/anything-that-floats
(It seems I like saying "It seems")
Wolfman2000: Yes
programmatically
Yes
no SVG importing?
Can this canvas be given a width and height, but with a height "cap" of sorts to force scrolling in one direction or another?
lazni: You can drawImage svg onto a canvas
was interpreting "you" as meaning a page developer, not a user
Dashiva: Only in Opera
(I think)
Probably
and not in the spec
(except via )
is more a web developer than a user these days.
But I expect it will spread
Wolfman2000: It has a width and a height, just like an
Wolfman2000: you want something like http://yuiblog.com/assets/slicing/vr_test.html?
blog post: http://www.yuiblog.com/blog/2008/06/23/slicing/
hmm...unsure the best way to phrase this.
Wolfman2000: It's just a rectangle on the page (of the given width/height), and scrolls like any other static object on a page

I want to turn a java application that I have and make it use the power of HTML5.  http://beta.pumpproedits.com/java/PPEdits.zip  <-- that's the app and the libraries. It's meant for creating machine dance step data for an arcade game, and the charts scroll downward.
can't easily run Java applications
I'll get you a screenshot then if I can.

If you want some kind of scrolling within the content of the (rather than having it be like a large where the whole page can scroll to reveal parts of it), then you'll just have to write code to detect user input and to offset all your drawing functions
http://tinypic.com/3ia31x0i Not just scrolling. Adding elements.

Either way, I can "possibly" do this with
s and lots of s. I just want to try to take advantage of what HTML5 has to offer.
Might be easier to do it with SVG than with canvas
heyo
Philip`: javascript and SVG? Well, the charts that I generate are SVG already.
http://beta.pumpproedits.com/chart/quick/143/rhythm <-- one of the recent ones, showing off a new game mode. (Firefox views it best)
Still...I could have thought plain <svg> files couldn't have a <script> or <title> tag.
How exactly can I combine SVG and Javascript?

Wolfman2000: You can use <script>s in SVG files, and also you can embed SVG inside an XHTML page (sent as application/xhtml+xml, not text/html yet) in order to use normal HTML form inputs and scripts and so on
You can embed SVG in text/html in Firefox with html5.enable and in IE9, and probably in other browsers at some point.
html5.enable is at true right now
Wolfman2000: Not by default
...wonder how I turned it on then
Then you can stick <svg><circle r=100 full=red></circle></svg> in your HTML documents and get SVG as part of the DOM.  (Except I don't know SVG, so that might not work.)
(Do void elements auto-close in SVG-in-text/html?)
Restricting yourself to IE9 + Firefox-with-non-standard-options is probably a bit excessively anti-user
Maybe.
Then please suggest a good alternative
Doing it in application/xhtml+xml will work in every browser except IE8 (and older IEs)
AryehGregor: You have to say <circle></circle> or <circle/>
The parser doesn't know the details of all SVG elements
Ah, so <circle /> does work.
This works in Firefox with html5.enable: data:text/html,<!doctype html><svg width=200 height=200><circle cx=100 cy=100 r=100 fill=red /></svg>
Hurrah.
Philip`: since I'm using HTML5 on my website primarily, what requires changing for it to work as application/xhtml+xml?
Wolfman2000, IE < 9 doesn't work with application/xhtml+xml.
Nor does it support SVG at all, in fact.
AryehGregor: besides IE
AryehGregor: and circle isn't an empty element in SVG anyway
Oh, then you just have to make sure it's well-formed, or else it will die with a fatal error.
So it's kind of inconvenient.
Probably easier to use <object> for now.  You can still have <script> inside the SVG file itself, as I understand it.
so HTML5 and XHTML use the same thing?
...I'll rephrase better. All I have to do is make sure my HTML5 is well formed and pass the right mime type, and it magically works?
Yes, except it's not magic because you're following all the steps needed to make it work :-)
I wasn't expecting magic
I think most of my code is well formed as is at least.
It's generally very difficult to guarantee well-formedness, so you should probably avoid it as much as possible
and only use XHTML for pages that really require it
(There's also quite a few subtle behavioural differences, which can break things)
Philip`: the only pages that require XML are the generated charts...and hopefully the new javascript chart editor I want to get working.
so...what's the best validator to use in this case? W3 doesn't offer XHTML5
AryehGregor might be sensible in suggesting using <object> instead, so most of your page is plain old HTML and it just embeds a minimal amount of SVG XML in the <object>
and you can put scripts in the outer HTML page, and have them manipulate the inner SVG page's DOM
http://html5.validator.nu/ should work
Wolfman2000: also be carefull with user input
unicode encoding and such
...no more summary attribute? huh
data-summary and provide your own behaviour
I meant for <table>
(yes, I have a valid use for table)
I meant as a workaround
http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/tabular-data.html#attr-table-summary
summary is allowed, although it's controversial.
The bit above that has lots of suggested better ways of expressing summary-style text
Lots to consider...if nothing else, thanks for the updates

Hello world!
when is Ubuntu finally going to work with projectors normally?
maybe with KMS
I think Lucid will use KMS with nouveau and intel
I had to actually remove xorg.conf, log out, and log in again to fix issues after letting Ubuntu write to it to make it recognize my normal resolution again
guesses it will be a nonissue in less than five years
also, several icons are now in the wrong place
GNOME panels always randomly reorganize themselves when you log out and back in.
It's infuriating.
Xfce panels are far superior in all respects.
it's mostly weird they haven't fixed this
you'd think fundamental problems like this would have been fixed ages ago
That's not the kind of remark I'd expect from a software developer.
using a projector is sort of an important use case
I'd have thought you'd realize that things that seem obviously important to you might be less important or more difficult to fix than you'd think.
Argh, now I've missed the chance to make the "more functional hello world" joke
Most people don't use projectors ever.  You give talks all the time, so you use projectors regularly.
What use does a normal person have for a projector?
I don't think I've ever used one in my life.
lots of people give talks

AryehGregor: Lucky you
A tiny minority of people give talks.
www-tag email is now classified as spam
way to go Opera Mail
AryehGregor: I'm not sure that is true
annevk, wait, so is that a false positive or not?
has got rejeced by Edinburgh uni
Presentations are common in business and in academia
jgraham, I don't give talks, therefore nobody does.  Very simple.
Yes, yes, I know.
*rejected
meetings and presentations are all the rage in corporate culture
also in university

gsnedders: Oh. Their loss really
also what jgraham said
gsnedders, :(
Anyway, obviously Ubuntu hasn't received too many complaints about projectors not working, so that favors my hypothesis.
projectors work

Not working well.  Whatever.

it's just that a) it requires Ubuntu writing to xorg.conf b) because of that it requires logging out and logging in c) because of the xorg.conf changes my original resolution can no longer be selected (which is somewhat weird admittedly, 16:10) d) it therefore requires me to sudo rm xorg.conf and log out and log in again...
none of this should be needed, of course
jgraham: I guess I'll have to follow the example of others on the Carakan team and go to Glasgow :P
Why does it need to write to xorg.conf?
Doesn't X autoconfigure these days?
has written a 566-word post in response to the authoring conformance thread: trim down or post?

Shorter than what I end up writing without meaning too...
trims it down some

I've been meaning to start posting blog-like stuff on aryeh.name, but never got around to setting it up.

no ...

gsnedders, gsnedders - have you come to realize the brilliance of LysKOM yet?
MikeSmith: Don't tell me you're a kommie!
it's the greatest
what do we need IRC for, when we have LysKOM?
I thought you were fucked up before, but now...
What could be btter than a messanging system that allows for threads to form arbitary directed graphs?
It makes designing good UI so easy
or even, what do we need e-mail for? or the Web?
jgraham: Email does that to
jgraham: You just have a In-Reply-To header with an arbitrary list of message ids
gsnedders: Curiously all email clients just pretend like that is impossible
_You_ try designing a good graph-based UI
Dashiva: Well I might design the protocol in such a way that it didn't exclude good UI in the first place
jgraham: So do semi-sane KOM clients
jgraham: How would you design a graph-based protocol so as to not require graph-based UI?
Dashiva: I would not design a graph-based protocol
Or rather I would limit it to trees
(I certianly wouldn't tout the graphiness as a desirable feature)
gsnedders: There are semi-sane KOM clients?
jgraham: Maybe
jgraham: In that protocol that is email + ignoring references that would create cycles, that is already the case
So it seems like a solved problem
